title: This Stock Indicator Points to the End of the Bull Market
text:
Text size

The bull market will be in trouble if the short-interest ratio continues to rise as quickly it has so far this year.

This will come as a surprise to contrarian-oriented investors, who have long believed that a rising short-interest ratio is bullish. But that belief is wrong, according to Matthew Ringgenberg, a finance professor at the University of Utah.

Those who sell a stock short, of course, are betting that its price will decline. They sell shares that they have borrowed from a broker, hoping to be able to buy them back in the future at lower prices and repay the broker loan. The short-interest ratio reflects the total number of shares that have been sold short and have yet to be repurchased—expressed as a ratio by dividing it by the total number of all shares outstanding.

At the end of August, Ringgenberg told Barron’s, this ratio was more than 20% higher than where it stood as recently as the beginning of this year. This increase is “one of the steepest” since immediately before 2008, he said, when the ratio jumped nearly 40% over a similarly short period.

To appreciate why the contrarians are wrong about the short-interest ratio, consider an index Ringgenberg and his co-researchers constructed that represents the extent to which any given month’s short-selling ratio is above or below trend. They found that higher readings are bearish and lower readings bullish, which is directly the opposite of what the contrarians have heretofore assumed.

In fact, they found that, over the four decades ended in 2014, this index was “arguably the strongest known predictor of aggregate stock returns,” outperforming any of a number of popular indicators used to forecast returns—such as price/earnings or price/book ratios.

Why should short sellers collectively have this unique ability? After all, the stock market is notoriously difficult to predict, with most investors doing no better than random guesses.

The answer, according to Ringgenberg, is that short sellers must jump over a number of hurdles that other investors do not have to overcome. For example, it can be costly to borrow shares to sell them short, and for some stocks it can be difficult finding borrowable shares at any price. Furthermore, since the potential loss of a short sale is infinite, the practice is especially risky.

These hurdles discourage all but the most committed and confident of traders from ever selling short. That doesn’t mean they will always be right. But it does mean that, on balance, their outlook on a stock is more likely to be correct than those who merely purchase stocks, according to Ringgenberg.

So why did contrarians come to interpret the short-interest ratio in precisely the wrong way? Ringgenberg speculates that contrarians were swayed by the entirely plausible theory that a high level of short interest represents a large amount of future buying, since those shorts eventually will have to be covered. And it is true, he says, that “lots of short covering can lead to a positive price bump.”

The key, however, is that this bump tends only to be temporary, Ringgenberg points out.



Even though the short-interest ratio has spiked over the past several months, signaling that the more-often-than-not correct short sellers are anticipating lower prices, the ratio hasn’t yet risen into the outright negative territory that would tempt some to sell everything and head for the hills. What’s worrisome is not the absolute level of short-selling volume—at least not yet—but the trend.

The good news, according to Ringgenberg, is that “short sellers are not anticipating the kind of market downturn we saw in 2008.” The bad news is that the “data does show some evidence of a possible downturn.”

Consider yourself warned.

Mark Hulbert is a regular contributor to Barron’s. His Hulbert Ratings tracks investment newsletters that pay a flat fee to be audited. He can be reached at mark@hulbertratings.com
